Subsection.Text: Any area of a train that is intended for use by a person using a wheelchair, including a wheelchair-accessible cabin or a wheelchair-accessible food service area, must have a path of travel that is accessible to persons with disabilities from that area to any adjacent rail car, if that adjacent rail car contains a mobility aid space, transfer seat or wheelchair-accessible washroom.
A train must have a path of travel that is accessible to persons with disabilities between a wheelchair-accessible shower facility and a wheelchair-accessible cabin.
A diaphragm on a train must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clauses 5.1.1(a) to (d) of CSA B651-18; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have vertical handholds that are located on both sides of the diaphragm.

Subsection.Text: In this section, diaphragm means the passageway between rail cars.

Section.Text: Passenger seats on a train must be equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: movable armrests on at least 10% of the seats, which seats are evenly distributed throughout each rail car, except a food service rail car;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: handholds on the back of all aisle passenger seats; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if there are call buttons, call buttons that are

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: tactilely discernible and colour-contrasted with their background, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: operable using minimal force.

Section.Text: Trains must be equipped with tactile row markers, in raised characters and Braille, that are installed, either permanently or temporarily, on the sides of passenger seats and above the armrests or adjacent to the mechanisms for opening overhead bins.
A mobility aid space on a train must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have a clear floor area of at least 815 mm by 1,650 mm;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with a call button that is in a location within the reach of the person who is seated in the mobility aid space, that is tactilely discernible and colour-contrasted with its background and that is operable using minimal force; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with a table or counter for food service which, if located in a food service rail car that contains tables, meets the requirements set out in clauses 6.7.1.2 and 6.7.1.3 of CSA B651-18.

Section.Text: A transfer seat on a train must be equipped with a table or counter for food service.

Section.MarginalNote: Mandatory mobility aid space and transfer seat

Subsection.Text: A train must, in each class of service, have at least two adjacent mobility aid spaces and two adjacent transfer seats, as well as a number of additional mobility aid spaces and a number of additional transfer seats equal to one mobility aid space and one transfer seat for every 75 passenger seats.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Maximum of two mobility aid spaces
Subsection.Text: There must be no more than two mobility aid spaces in each rail car.

A food service rail car that offers passenger seats must have at least two mobility aid spaces. In the case of a bi-level food service rail car, there must be at least two mobility aid spaces that are located on the lower level of the rail car.
At least one rail car of a train must have a space for the storage of at least one mobility aid.
A mobility aid must be stored on a train in a manner that protects it from damage, including by using an anchoring system or by placing it in an area that is not intended for use by passengers.

Section.Text: A train must have available on board

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at least five passenger safety features cards that are in large print and at least five passenger safety features cards that are in Braille; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at least five electronic devices that provide passenger safety information in an audio and visual format and permit a person with a disability to adjust the volume of the audio output and the size of the font.

Section.Text: If a rail car is equipped with a window emergency exit, the window emergency exit must be identified by a contrasting colour strip around the perimeter and by tactile and Braille signage.
A washroom on a train, other than a wheelchair-accessible washroom, must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clause 6.3 of CSA B651-18, except clause 6.3.1.1(a) and except that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the reference to “clause 4.2” in clause 6.2.4.1 must be read as excluding clause 4.2.2,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the reference to “clause 5.2” in clause 6.3.2 must be read as excluding clause 5.2.2, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the reference to “clause 6.2.3” in clause 6.3.1.1(b) must be read as excluding clauses 6.2.3.1(c) and (d); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with at least two call buttons or two other devices for signalling an emergency that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: are located such that at least one button or device is not more than 450 mm above the floor and at least one other button or device is 800 mm to 1,100 mm above the floor,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: are colour-contrasted with their background and identified by tactile and Braille signage, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: are operable using minimal force.

Section.Text: A wheelchair-accessible washroom on a train must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clause 6.3 of CSA B651-18, except clause 6.3.1.1(a);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide a clear area of at least 1,500 mm by 1,500 mm; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with at least two call buttons or two other devices for signalling an emergency that meet the requirements set out in paragraph 110(b).

Subsection.Text: Each rail car on a train that has a mobility aid space, except a food service rail car, must have at least one wheelchair-accessible washroom.
If a food service rail car has one or more washrooms, at least one of them must be a wheelchair-accessible washroom.

Section.Text: A menu display board in a food service rail car on a train must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be positioned at a height that allows it to be easily seen by a person using a wheelchair;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be positioned to avoid shadow areas and glare and have a glare-free surface;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be colour-contrasted with its background; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clauses 4.5.3 to 4.5.5 of CSA B651-18.

Section.Text: A counter in a food service rail car on a train must meet the requirements set out in clauses 6.7.1.2 and 6.7.1.3 of CSA B651-18.

Section.MarginalNote: Location of food service rail car
Section.Text: A food service rail car on a train must be adjacent to a rail car that has a mobility aid space or a rail car that has a wheelchair-accessible cabin.
An on-board entertainment system on a train must be equipped to permit a person with a disability to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: access entertainment content that offers closed captioning and audio description and that is the same entertainment content that is offered to the other passengers or, if that is not possible, that is comparable entertainment content; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: start, stop and pause the entertainment content, turn on and off the closed captioning and audio description, change the language of choice, control the volume and select channels

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: through an interface that meets the requirements for an interface that are set out in the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if the interface has not been designed to be used with the on-board entertainment system, through a tactile template overlay affixed to the interface.

Subsection.Text: If a pre-existing train referred to in subsection 87(4) has an on-board entertainment system that does not offer closed captioning and audio description, the train must be equipped with personal electronic devices in a number that is sufficient to accommodate the number of persons with disabilities who have made a request for such a device.

The personal electronic devices must be pre-loaded with — or the train must provide wireless streaming of — entertainment content that offers closed captioning and audio description and that is the same entertainment content that is offered to the other passengers or, if that is not possible, that is comparable entertainment content.
A cabin on a train, other than a wheelchair-accessible cabin, must be equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: operating controls that meet the requirements set out in clause 4.2 of CSA B651-18, except clause 4.2.2;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: doors that meet the requirements set out in clause 5.2 of CSA B651-18, except clauses 5.2.1, 5.2.2 and 5.2.9.2 and except that the reference to “clause 4.2” in clause 5.2.7.1(a) must be read as excluding clause 4.2.2; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: at least two call buttons or two other devices for signalling an emergency that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: are located such that at least one is not more than 450 mm above the floor, and at least one other is 800 mm to 1,100 mm above the floor,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: are colour-contrasted with their background and identified by tactile and Braille signage, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: are operable using minimal force.

Subsection.Text: If there are objects that protrude more than 100 mm from the wall in a standard cabin, the objects must be cane-detectable at or below 680 mm from the floor or their undersides must be at a height of at least 2,030 mm from the floor.

Section.Text: A wheelchair-accessible cabin on a train must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have a clear floor area that meets the requirements set out in clause 4.1(b) of CSA B651-18;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with operating controls that meet the requirements set out in clause 4.2 of CSA B651-18;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clause 4.4.2 of CSA B651-18;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with an entry door that is identified by the International Symbol of Access and meets the requirements set out in clause 5.2 of CSA B651-18;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with at least two call buttons or two other devices for signalling an emergency that meet the requirements of paragraph 118(1)(c); and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: be adjacent to a wheelchair-accessible washroom or have a path of travel adjacent to the cabin that is accessible to persons with disabilities and that provides access to a wheelchair-accessible washroom.

Section.Text: A train that has cabins must have at least two wheelchair-accessible cabins that are adjacent to each other.

A shower facility on a train, other than a wheelchair-accessible shower facility, must meet the requirements set out in clause 6.5 of CSA B651-18, except clauses 6.5.5.1, 6.5.5.2 and 6.5.5.3(c)(i) and except that the reference to “clause 4.2” in clause 6.2.3.3(a) must be read as excluding clause 4.2.2.
A wheelchair-accessible shower facility on a train must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clause 6.5 of CSA B651-18 except clauses 6.5.5.1 and 6.5.5.2;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have an interior clear area of at least 900 mm by 1,500 mm;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: have a clear floor area in front of the shower entrance of at least 900 mm by 1,500 mm, with the 1,500 mm dimension parallel to the shower entrance; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: be located near to a wheelchair-accessible cabin.

Section.Text: A train that has a standard shower facility must also have at least one wheelchair-accessible shower facility.

Subsection.Text: An interior door and doorway on a train must meet the requirements set out in clauses 5.2.1 and 5.2.6 to 5.2.8 of CSA B651-18.
An interior door must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an automatic or semi-automatic door, incorporate devices that prevent the door from closing while a person is in the doorway and, in the case of an automatic door that connects rail cars, open and close the door automatically on detecting the movement of a person toward or away from the door;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be marked with visual indicators if 75% of the door’s surface is composed of a transparent material;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a door to an enclosed space in an area that has no other exit doors, have a safety mechanism that is not a deadbolt and is capable of being manipulated from the outside; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a door that is intended for use by a person using a mobility aid, meet the requirements set out in clauses 4.2.2 and 5.2.2 of CSA B651-18.

Section.Text: An exterior door on a train must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clause 5.2.1 of CSA B651-18;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have a handrail

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: on each side of the door, fitted internally as close as is feasible to the outer wall of the rail car, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: on only one side of

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: a doorway that is fitted with a device for boarding or disembarking, such as a lift, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: a trap door to which stairs are attached; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the door is intended to be used by a person using a mobility aid, meet the requirements set out in clauses 5.2.2(a) and (b) of CSA B651-18.

Section.Text: Handrails on a train must meet the requirements set out in clauses 5.3.1 and 5.3.2 of CSA B651-18.
The floors of a train must meet the requirements set out in clauses 4.3.1 to 4.3.3 of CSA B651-18.
Tactile attention indicator surfaces on a train must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be located at the top of stairs and at any other location where there is an unprotected drop-off edge and a change in elevation greater than 250 mm or where the ratio of the slope to surface is steeper than 1:3; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clauses 4.3.5.2(a) and (b), 4.3.5.3.1 and 4.3.5.3.4 of CSA B651-18.

Section.Text: Operating controls on a train must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clauses 4.2.1, 4.2.3 to 4.2.6 and 4.2.8 of CSA B651-18; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if they are intended to be used by a person using a wheelchair, meet the requirements set out in clause 4.2.2 of CSA B651-18.

Subsection.Text: Signage on a train, other than a menu display board referred to in section 113, must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: indicate any services, facilities, amenities or equipment that are offered and the direction to follow in order to access them;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be positioned to avoid shadow areas and glare and have a glare-free surface;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be colour-contrasted with its background; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: except in the case of electronic signage, meet the requirements set out in clauses 4.5.3 to 4.5.7 of CSA B651-18.

Subsection.Text: Electronic signage must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have letters, numbers, symbols and pictographs that slowly scroll across the screen and are colour-contrasted with their background but are not in red on a black background; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clauses 4.5.3 to 4.5.5 of CSA B651-18.

Section.Text: If a train is equipped with an elevator, the elevator must meet the requirements set out in clause 5.6.1 of CSA B651-18.

If a train is equipped with an alarm system, including in a cabin, the alarm system must consist of both a visual alarm and an audible alarm. A visual alarm must meet the requirements set out in clause 5.7.1 of CSA B651-18.

Subsection.Text: A train and any related facilities, including any amenities and equipment used in them, that are subject to any requirements of this Division must be in good working order and properly maintained.

If any facilities, amenities or equipment that are referred to in subsection (1) are not in good working order, they must be repaired as soon as possible and, until they are repaired, measures must be taken that will result in a substantially equivalent or greater level of accessibility for persons with disabilities.

Section.Text: Unless otherwise specified, this Division applies to every marine carrier that provides a service for the transportation of passengers between two or more provinces or from a point of origin in Canada to a point of destination in a foreign country if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the service is provided by means of a ferry of 1,000 gross tonnage or more; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the carrier offers on-board services to passengers.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), the provisions of this Division, except sections 143, 144, 153, 164 and 178, do not apply to a pre-existing ferry.
Sections 138, 140 and 142 apply to a pre-existing ferry with respect to any step box, ramp, gangway or stairs that are portable and not integrated with the pre-existing ferry.

If a carrier makes a modification — other than a modification to a mechanical, electrical or plumbing system or a modification carried out for an aesthetic purpose or for maintenance or repair — to any amenity or equipment that is used in a pre-existing ferry, the carrier must ensure that the modified amenity or equipment meets the requirements of this Division, except in the following circumstances:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the dimensions of the ferry or of the amenity or equipment are unalterable;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the structural integrity or safe operation of the ferry or of the amenity or equipment would be materially affected; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the principal purpose of the amenity or equipment would be fundamentally altered.

Subsection.Text: In this section, a pre-existing ferry means a ferry that was

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: purchased or leased by the carrier before the day on which this section comes into force; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: purchased or leased by the carrier on or after the day on which this section comes into force, if the carrier submitted the call for tenders in respect of that ferry before that day.

Section.Text: This Division does not apply in respect of a ferry that is leased by a carrier on a short-term basis in order to respond to an emergency or to replace a ferry that requires repairs due to an unforeseen mechanical failure.
A carrier must ensure that any ferry that it owns, operates or leases and any related facilities, including any amenities and equipment used in them, meet the requirements set out in this Division.
A step box that is used to assist a person with a disability to board or disembark from a ferry must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be of sound construction;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have a tread surface that is firm and slip-resistant;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: have a glare-free surface; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: have a top outer edge that is marked by a contrasting colour strip that runs the full width of the box.

Section.Text: A ferry must be equipped with a step box if the riser height of the first or last step of any stairs that are used by passengers to board or disembark is greater than the riser height of the other steps.
A ramp or gangway that is used to assist a person with a disability, including a person in a mobility aid, to board or disembark from a ferry must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have a contrasting colour strip that runs the full width of its bottom edge;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have raised edges to prevent a mobility aid from rolling off the edge of the ramp;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: have a slip-resistant surface; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: be capable of supporting a minimum weight of 363 kg.

Section.Text: If a ferry terminal does not permit level boarding of a ferry, the ferry must have a vehicle deck that is used for the boarding and disembarking of passengers or be equipped with a ramp or gangway.

Subsection.Text: Any stairs that are used to board or disembark from a ferry, and any interior stairs on a ferry, must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clauses 5.4.1 and 5.4.2 of CSA B651-18;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have handrails that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: are located on both sides of the stairs,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: are located at a uniform height of 860 mm to 920 mm, measured vertically from the leading edge of the tread, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clause 5.3.1 of CSA B651-18; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: have tactile attention indicator surfaces that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clauses 4.3.5.2(a) and (b), 4.3.5.3.1 and 4.3.5.3.4 of CSA B651-18,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: are located at the top of the stairs, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: commence one tread length before the top of the stairs, extend the full width of the stairs and measure from 600 mm to 650 mm in length.

Subsection.Text: For a period of two years beginning on the day on which this section comes into force, subsection (1) does not apply in respect of stairs that are portable and not integrated with the ferry.

Section.Text: An on-board wheelchair that is available on a ferry must have footrests and wheel locks.
At least one on-board wheelchair must be available on each deck of a ferry, except a deck that is not accessible to a person using a wheelchair.

Subsection.Text: A path of travel on a ferry is accessible to persons with disabilities if it meets the requirements set out in subsections (2) and (3) and in clauses 4.4.2, 5.1.1 and 5.1.2 of CSA B651-18.

If access to the path of travel from an exterior door requires passage through a hall or path or requires a 90-degree or similar turn, then that hall, path or turning space must have a minimum clear width of 1,115 mm and a minimum clear diameter of 1,500 mm.
The aisle width between passenger seats must be sufficient to accommodate an on-board wheelchair.

Section.Text: Every path of travel that is on a ferry and that is intended for use by passengers must be a path of travel that is accessible to persons with disabilities.
Passenger seats on a ferry must be equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: movable armrests on at least 10% of the seats, which seats are evenly distributed throughout each passenger seating area, except a food service area or lounge area; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if there are call buttons, call buttons that are

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: tactilely discernible and colour-contrasted with their background, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: operable using minimal force.

Section.Text: If a marine carrier offers assigned passenger seats to passengers, the assigned passenger seats must be equipped with tactile row markers, in raised characters and Braille, that are installed, either permanently or temporarily, on the sides of the seats and above the armrests.
A mobility aid space on a ferry must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have a clear floor area of at least 815 mm by 1,650 mm;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be positioned such that a person using a mobility aid has adequate manoeuvring space to enter it; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: have a table or counter that meets the requirements set out in clauses 6.7.1.2 and 6.7.1.3 of CSA B651-18.

Section.Text: A transfer seat on a ferry must be equipped with a table or counter for food service.

Section.MarginalNote: Mandatory mobility aid space and transfer seat

Subsection.Text: A ferry must, in each passenger seating area, have at least two adjacent mobility aid spaces and two adjacent transfer seats.
A food service area or a lounge area that offers passenger seats must have at least two adjacent mobility aid spaces.
Each deck of a ferry must have a space for the storage of at least one mobility aid.
A mobility aid must be stored on a ferry in a manner that protects it from damage, including by using an anchoring system or by placing it in an area that is not intended for use by passengers.

Section.Text: Each passenger deck of a ferry must have available on board

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at least five passenger safety features cards that are in large print and at least five passenger safety features cards that are in Braille; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at least one electronic device that provides passenger safety information in an audio and visual format and permits a person with a disability to adjust the volume of the audio output and the size of the font.

Section.Text: If a ferry is equipped with a window emergency exit, the window emergency exit must be identified by a contrasting colour strip around the perimeter and by tactile and Braille signage.
A washroom on a ferry, other than a wheelchair-accessible washroom, must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clause 6.3 of CSA B651-18, except clause 6.3.1.1(a) and except that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the reference to “clause 4.2” in clause 6.2.4.1 must be read as excluding clause 4.2.2,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the reference to “clause 5.2” in clause 6.3.2 must be read as excluding clause 5.2.2, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the reference to “clause 6.2.3” in clause 6.3.1.1(b) must be read as excluding clauses 6.2.3.1(c) and 6.2.3.1(d); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with at least two call buttons or two other devices for signalling an emergency that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: are located such that at least one button or device is not more than 450 mm above the floor and at least one other button or device is 800 mm to 1,100 mm above the floor,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: are colour-contrasted with their background and identified by tactile and Braille signage, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: are operable using minimal force.

Section.Text: A wheelchair-accessible washroom on a ferry must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clause 6.3 of CSA B651-18, except clause 6.3.1.1(a);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide a clear area of at least 1,500 mm by 1,500 mm; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with at least two call buttons or two other devices for signalling an emergency that meet the requirements set out in paragraph 155(b).

Section.Text: If a deck, a food service area or a lounge area of a ferry has one or more washrooms, at least one of them must be a wheelchair-accessible washroom.
A menu display board in a food service area on a ferry must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be positioned at a height that allows it to be easily seen by a person using a wheelchair;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be positioned to avoid shadow areas and glare and have a glare-free surface;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be colour-contrasted with its background; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clauses 4.5.3 to 4.5.5 of CSA B651-18.

Section.Text: A counter in a food service area or a lounge area on a ferry must meet the requirements set out in clauses 6.7.1.2 and 6.7.1.3 of CSA B651-18.

At least 5% of the total number of tables in a food service area or lounge area on a ferry must be identified by the International Symbol of Access and meet the requirements set out in clauses 6.7.1.1 to 6.7.1.3 of CSA B651-18.

Subsection.Text: In a food service area or a lounge area on a ferry, a handrail must be provided along the side of a food-service counter and the floor area adjacent to the counter must meet the requirements set out in clauses 4.4.2, 5.1.1 and 5.1.2 of CSA B651-18.
Lineup guides in a food service area or a lounge area on a ferry must meet the requirements set out in clause 5.1.3 of CSA B651-18.

Section.Text: A counter that is used for serving passengers on a ferry, except a food-service counter referred to in subsection 161(1), must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have at least one section that meets the requirements set out in clauses 6.7.1.2 and 6.7.1.3 of CSA B651-18;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be free of any object that could impede verbal or visual communications between a passenger and a member of personnel; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: have a glare-free surface and be colour-contrasted with its background.

Section.Text: An on-board entertainment system on a ferry must be equipped to permit a person with a disability to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: access entertainment content that offers closed captioning and audio description and that is the same entertainment content that is offered to the other passengers or, if that is not possible, that is comparable entertainment content; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: start, stop and pause the entertainment content, turn on and off the closed captioning and audio description, change the language of choice, control the volume and select channels

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: through an interface that meets the requirements for an interface that are set out in the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if the interface has not been designed to be used with the on-board entertainment system, through a tactile template overlay affixed to the interface.

Subsection.Text: If a pre-existing ferry referred to in subsection 135(4) has an on-board entertainment system that does not offer closed captioning and audio description, the ferry must be equipped with personal electronic devices in a number that is sufficient to accommodate the number of persons with disabilities who have made a request for such a device.

The personal electronic devices must be pre-loaded with — or the ferry must provide wireless streaming of — entertainment content that offers closed captioning and audio description and that is the same entertainment content that is offered to the other passengers or, if that is not possible, that is comparable entertainment content.
A cabin on a ferry, other than a wheelchair-accessible cabin, must be equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: operating controls that meet the requirements set out in clause 4.2 of CSA B651-18, except clause 4.2.2;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: doors that meet the requirements set out in clause 5.2 of CSA B651-18, except clauses 5.2.1, 5.2.2 and 5.2.9.2 and except that the reference to “clause 4.2” in clause 5.2.7.1(a) must be read as excluding clause 4.2.2; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: at least two call buttons or two other devices for signalling an emergency that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: are located such that at least one button or device is not more than 450 mm above the floor and at least one other button or device is 800 mm to 1,100 mm above the floor,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: are colour-contrasted with their background and identified by tactile and Braille signage, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: are operable using minimal force.

Subsection.Text: If there are objects that protrude more than 100 mm from the wall in a standard cabin, the objects must be cane-detectable at or below 680 mm from the floor or their undersides must be at a height of at least 2,030 mm from the floor.

Section.Text: A wheelchair-accessible cabin on a ferry must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have a clear floor area that meets the requirements set out in clause 4.1(b) of CSA B651-18;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with operating controls that meet the standards set out in clause 4.2 of CSA B651-18;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clause 4.4.2 of CSA B651-18;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with an entry door that is identified by the International Symbol of Access and meets the requirements set out in clause 5.2 of CSA B651-18;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with at least two call buttons or two other devices for signalling an emergency that meet the requirements of paragraph 165(1)(c); and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: be adjacent to a wheelchair-accessible washroom or be near a wheelchair-accessible washroom on the same deck.

Section.Text: At least five percent of the total number of cabins on the ferry must be wheelchair-accessible and at least two of the wheelchair-accessible cabins must be adjacent to each other.

A shower facility on a ferry, other than a wheelchair-accessible shower facility, must meet the requirements set out in clause 6.5 of CSA B651-18, except clauses 6.5.5.1, 6.5.5.2 and 6.5.5.3(c)(i) and except that the reference to “clause 4.2” in clause 6.2.3.3(a) must be read as excluding clause 4.2.2.
A wheelchair-accessible shower facility on a ferry must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clause 6.5 of CSA B651-18 except clauses 6.5.5.1 and 6.5.5.2;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have an interior clear area of at least 900 mm by 1,500 mm;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: have a clear floor area in front of the shower entrance of at least 900 mm by 1,500 mm, with the 1,500 mm dimension parallel to the shower entrance; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: be located on the same deck as a wheelchair-accessible cabin.

Section.Text: A ferry that has a standard shower facility must also have at least one wheelchair-accessible shower facility.

Subsection.Text: An interior door and doorway on a ferry must meet the requirements set out in clauses 5.2.1 and 5.2.6 to 5.2.8 of CSA B651-18.
An interior door must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an automatic or semi-automatic door, incorporate devices that prevent the door from closing while a person is in the doorway and that open and close the door automatically on detecting the movement of a person toward or away from the door;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be marked with visual indicators if 75% of the door’s surface is composed of a transparent material;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a door to an enclosed space in an area that has no other exit doors, have a safety mechanism that is not a deadbolt and is capable of being manipulated from the outside; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a door that is intended for use by a person using a mobility aid, meet the requirements set out in clauses 4.2.2 and 5.2.2 of CSA B651-18.

Section.Text: An exterior door on a ferry must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clause 5.2.1 of CSA B651-18;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have a handrail

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: on each side of the door, fitted internally as close as is feasible to the outer wall of the ferry, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: on only one side of

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: a doorway that is fitted with a device for boarding or disembarking, such as a lift, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: a trap door to which stairs are attached; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the door is intended to be used by a person using a mobility aid, meet the requirements set out in clauses 5.2.2(a) and (b) of CSA B651-18.

Section.Text: Handrails on a ferry must meet the requirements set out in clauses 5.3.1 and 5.3.2 of CSA B651-18.
The floors of a ferry must meet the requirements set out in clauses 4.3.1 to 4.3.3 of CSA B651-18.
Tactile attention indicator surfaces on a ferry must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be located at the top of stairs and at any other location where there is an unprotected drop-off edge and a change in elevation greater than 250 mm or where the ratio of the slope to surface is steeper than 1:3; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clauses 4.3.5.2(a) and (b), 4.3.5.3.1 and 4.3.5.3.4 of CSA B651-18.

Section.Text: Operating controls on a ferry must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clauses 4.2.1, 4.2.3 to 4.2.6 and 4.2.8 of CSA B651-18; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if they are intended to be used by a person using a wheelchair, meet the requirements set out in clause 4.2.2 of CSA B651-18.

Subsection.Text: Signage on a ferry, other than a menu display board referred to in section 158, must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: indicate any services, facilities, amenities or equipment that are offered and of the direction to follow in order to access them;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be positioned to avoid shadow areas and glare and have a glare-free surface;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be colour-contrasted with its background; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: except in the case of electronic signage, meet the requirements set out in clauses 4.5.3 to 4.5.7 of CSA B651-18.

Subsection.Text: Electronic signage must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have letters, numbers, symbols and pictographs that slowly scroll across the screen and are colour-contrasted with their background but are not in red on a black background; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clauses 4.5.3 to 4.5.5 of CSA B651-18.

Subsection.Text: A ferry on which passengers are travelling for four consecutive hours or more must have a designated area for service dogs to relieve themselves that a person with a disability may reach by means of a path of travel that is accessible to persons with disabilities and that is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: identified by tactile and Braille signage; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: cleaned and maintained on a regular basis.

Subsection.Text: The ferry must have signage that indicates the direction to follow in order to access a designated relief area.

Section.Text: A ferry that has more than one deck must have at least one elevator that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: provides service from a vehicle deck to all passenger decks, except to a deck that does not have a housing to protect the elevator from the weather; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meets the requirements set out in clause 5.6.1 of CSA B651-18.

Section.Text: Each elevator on a ferry must have signage that warns passengers that the elevator may not be operational when the ferry’s roll exceeds the safe operating criteria established by the manufacturer of the elevator.

If a ferry is equipped with an alarm system, including in a cabin, the alarm system must provide both a visual alarm and an audible alarm. A visual alarm must meet the requirements set out in clause 5.7.1 of CSA B651-18.

Subsection.Text: A ferry and any related facilities, including any amenities and equipment used in them, that are subject to any requirements of this Division must be in good working order and properly maintained.

If any facilities, amenities or equipment that are referred to in subsection (1) are not in good working order, they must be repaired as soon as possible and, until they are repaired, measures must be taken that will result in a substantially equivalent or greater level of accessibility for persons with disabilities.

Section.Text: Unless otherwise specified, this Division applies to every bus carrier that provides a service for the transportation of passengers between two or more provinces and from a point of origin in Canada to a point of destination in a foreign country.
This Division does not apply to a bus carrier in respect of any of the following buses:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any bus that has a maximum carrying capacity of not more than 39 passengers;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any bus while it is being used in a charter service.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), the provisions of this Division, except sections 199 and 205, do not apply to a pre-existing bus.
Sections 188 and 189 apply to a pre-existing bus with respect to any lift, ramp or bridge plate that is portable and not integrated with the pre-existing bus.

If a carrier makes a modification — other than a modification to a mechanical, electrical or plumbing system or a modification carried out for an aesthetic purpose or for maintenance or repair — to any amenity or equipment that is used in a pre-existing bus, the carrier must ensure that the modified amenity or equipment meets the requirements of this Division, except in the following circumstances:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the dimensions of the bus or of the amenity or equipment are unalterable;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the structural integrity or safe operation of the bus or of the amenity or equipment would be materially affected; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the principal purpose of the amenity or equipment would be fundamentally altered.

Subsection.Text: In this section, a pre-existing bus means a bus that was

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: purchased or leased by the carrier before the day on which this section comes into force; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: purchased or leased by the carrier on or after the day on which this section comes into force, if the carrier submitted the call for tenders in respect of that bus before that day.

Section.Text: This Division does not apply in respect of a bus that is leased by a carrier on a short-term basis in order to respond to an emergency or to replace a bus that requires repairs due to an unforeseen mechanical failure.
A carrier must ensure that any bus that it owns, operates or leases and any related facilities, including any amenities and equipment used in them, meet the requirements set out in this Division.
A lift that is used to assist a person with a disability, including a person in a mobility aid, to board or disembark from a bus must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have handrails that are located on both sides of the lift and a slip-resistant surface; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be capable of supporting a minimum weight of 272 kg.

Section.Text: A ramp or bridge plate that is used to assist a person with a disability, including a person in a mobility aid, to board or disembark from a bus must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have a contrasting colour strip that runs the full width of its bottom edge;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have raised edges to prevent a mobility aid from rolling off the edge of the ramp;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: have a slip-resistant surface; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: be capable of supporting a minimum weight of 272 kg.

Section.Text: If a bus terminal does not permit level boarding of a bus and there is no lift, ramp or bridge plate available at the bus terminal, the bus must be equipped with a lift, ramp or bridge plate.
If a bus makes a stop at any place that is not at a terminal and where passengers are permitted to board and disembark, the bus must be equipped with a lift, ramp or bridge plate.
Any stairs that are used to board or disembark from a bus, and any interior stairs on a bus, must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clauses 5.4.1 and 5.4.2 of CSA B651-18;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have handrails that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: are located on both sides of the stairs,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: are located at a uniform height of 860 mm to 920 mm, measured vertically from the leading edge of the tread, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clause 5.3.1 of CSA B651-18;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: have tactile attention indicator surfaces that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clauses 4.3.5.2(a) and (b), 4.3.5.3.1 and 4.3.5.3.4 of CSA B651-18,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: are located at the top of the stairs, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: commence one tread length before the top of the stairs, extend the full width of the stairs and measure from 600 mm to 650 mm in length; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with lighting that accentuates the steps and handrails.

Section.Text: Passenger seats on a bus must be equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: movable armrests on all aisle and middle passenger seats;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: handholds on the back of all aisle passenger seats; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if there are call buttons, call buttons that are

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: tactilely discernible and colour-contrasted with their background, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: operable using minimal force.

Section.Text: A bus must be equipped with tactile row markers, in raised characters and Braille, that are installed, either permanently or temporarily, on the sides of passenger seats and above the armrests or adjacent to the mechanisms for opening overhead bins.

Section.MarginalNote: Priority seats for persons with disabilities
Section.Text: The first row of passenger seats on each side of a bus must be designated as priority seats for persons with disabilities and there must be signage that indicates that a person, other than a person with a disability, must vacate a priority seat if the seat is needed by a person with a disability.
A mobility aid space on a bus must have a clear floor area of at least 1,220 mm by 760 mm.
A bus must have at least two mobility aid spaces.

A bus must have a baggage compartment that allows for the storage of at least two mobility aids, each of which weighing no more than 227 kg and having a width of no more than 1,092 mm, a height of not more than 736 mm (with the seat and steering column collapsed) and a length of not more than 2,260.6 mm.
A bus that has any passenger safety features cards available on board must have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at least two passenger safety features cards that are in large print and at least two passenger safety features cards that are in Braille; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at least one electronic device that provides passenger safety information in an audio and visual format and permits a person with a disability to adjust the volume of the audio output and the size of the font.

Section.Text: If a bus is equipped with a window emergency exit, the window emergency exit must be identified by a contrasting colour strip around the perimeter and by tactile and Braille signage.
A washroom on a bus, other than a wheelchair-accessible washroom, must have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: doors that are equipped with handles, pulls, latches, locks and other devices that are operable using minimal force, with one hand in a closed-fist position, or by another method of operation that does not require tight grasping, pinching or twisting of the wrist ;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: toilets that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: are equipped with an automated flush control or a flush control that is operable using minimal force, with one hand in a closed-fist position, or by another method of operation that does not require tight grasping, pinching or twisting of the wrist, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: have a back support if the toilet has no seat lid;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: faucets that are equipped with

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: handles or other controls that are tactilely discernible, unless the water temperature is fixed to eliminate the risk of scalding,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of non-automated faucets, handles or other controls that are operable using minimal force, with one hand in a closed-fist position, or by another method of operation that does not require tight grasping, pinching or twisting of the wrist, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of automated faucets, a water activation motion sensor that turns the water on automatically when a hand is below the faucet;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: grab bars that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: are located on a wall beside the toilet,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: are rounded, slip-resistant and free of any sharp or abrasive elements,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: have an exterior diameter and a clearance from the wall surface to which they are attached that permit them to be easily grasped, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: are capable of supporting a minimum weight of 113.4 kg;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: toilet paper dispensers that are located so as to not interfere with the use of the grab bars;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: soap dispensers that are operable using minimal force, with one hand in a closed-fist position, or by another method of operation that does not require tight grasping, pinching or twisting of the wrist; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: at least one call button or other device for signalling an emergency that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is colour-contrasted with its background and identified by tactile and Braille signage, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is operable using minimal force.

Section.Text: A wheelchair-accessible washroom on a bus must meet the requirements set out in section 201 and must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have a door or other opening to the washroom that has sufficient space in front of it and that is wide enough to allow the entry of a person using a wheelchair;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have sufficient space to allow a person, with assistance, to transfer to and from a wheelchair and the toilet;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: have sufficient privacy, including with the use of retractable curtains or walls, to allow a support person or service dog to remain in the washroom with a person using a wheelchair; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with faucets that are positioned to be easily usable by a person using a wheelchair.

Section.Text: Every washroom on a bus must be a wheelchair-accessible washroom, unless the washroom does not have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a door or other opening to the washroom that has sufficient space in front of it and that is wide enough to allow the entry of a person using a wheelchair; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: sufficient space to allow a person, with assistance, to transfer to and from a wheelchair and the toilet.

Section.Text: An on-board entertainment system on a bus must be equipped to permit a person with a disability to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: access entertainment content that offers closed captioning and audio description and that is the same entertainment content that is offered to the other passengers or, if that is not possible, that is comparable entertainment content; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: start, stop and pause the entertainment content, turn on and off the closed captioning and audio description functions, change the language of choice, control the volume and select channels

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: through an interface that meets the requirements for an interface that are set out in the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if the interface has not been designed to be used with the on-board entertainment system, through a tactile template overlay affixed to the interface.

Subsection.Text: If a pre-existing bus referred to in subsection 185(4) has an on-board entertainment system that does not offer closed captioning and audio description, the bus must be equipped with personal electronic devices in a number that is sufficient to accommodate the number of persons with disabilities who have made a request for such a device.

The personal electronic devices must be pre-loaded with — or the bus must provide wireless streaming of — entertainment content that offers closed captioning and audio description and that is the same entertainment content that is offered to the other passengers or, if that is not possible, that is comparable entertainment content.

Section.Text: Grab bars, handholds and stanchions on a bus must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be sturdy, rounded and free of any sharp or abrasive element;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have an exterior diameter and a clearance from the surface to which they are attached that permit them to be easily grasped;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be colour-contrasted with their background;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: have a slip-resistant surface;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: be located

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: where passengers are required to pay fares or show proof of payment,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: close to mobility aid spaces,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: in priority seating areas, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: on each side of a door;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: be evenly distributed throughout the bus to assist persons with disabilities to safely board and disembark and to sit and stand;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: be located so as to not interfere with the turning and manoeuvring space that may be required by a person using a mobility aid to access a mobility aid space; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: if they are located at a door, be within the reach of a person standing at ground level and installed in a manner that ensures that they are inside the bus when the doors are closed.

Section.Text: The floors of a bus must meet the requirements set out in clauses 4.3.1 to 4.3.3 of CSA B651-18.
Tactile attention indicator surfaces on a bus must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be located at the top of stairs and at any other location where there is an unprotected drop-off edge and a change in elevation greater than 250 mm or where the ratio of the slope to surface is steeper than 1:3; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clauses 4.3.5.2(a) and (b), 4.3.5.3.1 and 4.3.5.3.4 of CSA B651-18.

Section.Text: Operating controls on a bus must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clauses 4.2.1, 4.2.3 to 4.2.6 and 4.2.8 of CSA B651-18; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if they are intended to be used by a person using a wheelchair, meet the requirements set out in clause 4.2.2 of CSA B651-18.

Subsection.Text: Signage on a bus must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: indicate any services, facilities, amenities or equipment that are offered and of the direction to follow in order to access them;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be positioned to avoid shadow areas and glare and have a glare-free surface;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be colour-contrasted with its background; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: except in the case of electronic signage, meet the requirements set out in clauses 4.5.3 to 4.5.7 of CSA B651-18.

Subsection.Text: Electronic signage must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have letters, numbers, symbols and pictographs that slowly scroll across the screen and are colour-contrasted with their background but are not in red on a black background; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements set out in clauses 4.5.3 to 4.5.5 of CSA B651-18.

Subsection.Text: A bus and any related facilities, including any amenities and equipment used in them, that are subject to any requirements of this Division must be in good working order and properly maintained.

If any facilities, amenities or equipment that are referred to in subsection (1) are not in good working order, they must be repaired as soon as possible and, until they are repaired, measures must be taken that will result in a substantially equivalent or greater level of accessibility for persons with disabilities.

Section.Text: Unless otherwise specified, this Division applies to every terminal operator who is the owner, operator or lessee of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an airport that is located in the national capital or a provincial capital or where at least 200,000 passengers emplaned and deplaned during each of the two preceding calendar years;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a rail terminal that serves a rail carrier referred to in paragraph 25(1)(b);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a ferry terminal that serves a marine carrier referred to in paragraph 25(1)(c); or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a bus terminal that serves a bus carrier that is subject to the requirements of Part 2.

Section.Text: This Division does not apply in respect of a terminal where the number of members of personnel who work at the terminal is, on average, fewer than 10, calculated on the basis of the daily average during each of the two preceding calendar years.

Section.MarginalNote: Prohibition — no charge for required services
Section.Text: It is prohibited for a terminal operator to impose a charge or fee for any service that the terminal operator is required by this Part to provide to any person.

A terminal operator must publish in electronic format on its website, or in another format if it does not have a website, information about the services or facilities available at the terminal for persons with disabilities, including information about

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the curbside zone, including where the curbside zone is located and how to request assistance to or from the curbside zone;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ground transportation from the terminal that is accessible to persons with disabilities, including whether a vehicle that is capable of carrying a non-folding or non-collapsible mobility aid is available;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the location of designated areas for service dogs to relieve themselves;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: transportation between facilities at a terminal that is accessible to persons with disabilities; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: wheelchair and electric cart services.

Subsection.Text: A terminal operator must, on the request of a person with a disability, without delay, assist the person with their baggage and with a wheelchair, and provide the following services to the person:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: providing the person with a wheelchair if needed by the person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: assisting the person to proceed between the general public area and the curbside zone, including by guiding; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: assisting the person to proceed between the curbside zone and the check-in area or, if there is no check-in area, between the curbside zone and a representative of a carrier, including by guiding.

Subsection.Text: However, a terminal operator is not required to provide a person with any assistance referred to in subsection (1) if a carrier is already providing that person with that assistance.

If a terminal operator enters into an agreement or arrangement with any service provider for the provision of ground transportation from the terminal, including by taxi, limousine, bus or rental vehicle, the terminal operator must ensure that the service provider provides transportation that is accessible to persons who are travelling with a mobility aid or any other assistive device or with a service dog, including transportation with vehicles that are capable of carrying non-folding or non-collapsible mobility aids.

If a terminal operator enters into an agreement or arrangement with any service provider for the provision of rental vehicles from the terminal, the terminal operator must ensure that the service provider provides rental vehicles that are equipped with hand-control systems.

Section.Text: Unless otherwise specified, this Division applies to every terminal operator referred to in section 212 and to every terminal operator who is the owner, operator or lessee of a port that permits the mooring of cruise ships.
This Division does not apply in respect of any area or any facility of a terminal that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is not intended for use by the public;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is not under the control of the terminal operator; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is a commercial establishment.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), sections 222, 226, 228 and 230 do not apply to a pre-existing terminal.

If a terminal operator makes a modification — other than a modification to a mechanical, electrical or plumbing system or a modification carried out for an aesthetic purpose or for maintenance or repair — to any amenity or equipment that is used in a pre-existing terminal, the terminal operator must ensure that the modified amenity or equipment meets the requirements of sections 222, 226, 228 and 230, except in the following circumstances:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the dimensions of the terminal or of the amenity or equipment are unalterable;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the structural integrity or safe operation of the terminal or of the amenity or equipment would be materially affected;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the principal purpose of the amenity or equipment would be fundamentally altered; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the Heritage Railway Stations Protection Act or any other Act of Parliament related to heritage protection would be contravened.

Subsection.Text: In this section, a pre-existing terminal means a terminal

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of which the terminal operator became the owner, operator or lessee before the day on which this section comes into force; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of which the terminal operator became the owner, operator or lessee on or after the day on which this section comes into force if the terminal operator submitted the call for tenders for the purchase, lease or construction of that terminal before the day on which this section comes into force.

Section.Text: A terminal operator must ensure that any terminal that it owns, operates or leases and any related facilities, including any amenities or equipment used in them, meet the requirements set out in this Division.
A terminal must meet the requirements set out in CSA B651-18, excluding clauses 5.6.2, 6.5.6, 6.6.2.2, 6.6.2.7.1, 6.7.3, 7 and 8.5 and all Annexes, commentary and figures.

A lift, ramp or stairs that are used at a terminal for the boarding or disembarkation of persons with disabilities must meet the requirements for a lift, ramp or stairs, as the case may be, that are set out in section 69, section 70 or subsection 71(1).
In the case of an airport, if the terminal does not permit level boarding of an aircraft, the terminal must be equipped with a lift, a ramp or portable stairs.

Subsection.Text: A terminal must have wheelchairs available for use by passengers in a number that is sufficient to accommodate the number of persons with disabilities who are likely to use them at any one time.
A wheelchair that is available for use by passengers at a terminal must have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: footrests and wheel locks; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a wheelchair used for boarding,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: movable armrests and an occupant restraint device, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a backrest of a height that permits the person using the wheelchair to be safely and easily transferred to and from a seat.

Section.Text: A terminal must have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: seats that are located along paths of travel at regular intervals of approximately 30 m; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in every boarding area, designated priority seats for persons with disabilities that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: are located so as to be close to members of personnel who are stationed at the boarding gate,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: are located so as to permit them to view screens or other boards that display information relating to departures or gate or track assignments, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: are marked with signage that specifies that persons with disabilities have priority access.

Subsection.Text: A designated area for service dogs to relieve themselves must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be identified by tactile and Braille signage; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be cleaned and maintained on a regular basis.

Subsection.Text: The terminal must have signage that indicates the direction to follow in order to access a designated relief area for service dogs.

A terminal must have a designated area for service dogs to relieve themselves that is located outside of the terminal and that a person with a disability may reach from the terminal by means of a path of travel that is accessible to persons with disabilities.

A terminal must have a designated area for service dogs to relieve themselves that a person with a disability may reach, from the area of the terminal into which access is strictly controlled, by means of a path of travel that is accessible to persons with disabilities and that does not require the person to exit and re-enter that area.

Section.Text: Sections 90 to 93, 96, 102, 109, 127 to 130, 190, 195, 197 and 206 apply, with any modifications that the circumstances require, in respect of any light-rail train and any shuttle bus that operates between any facilities of a terminal.

Section.MarginalNote: Obstruction due to repairs or maintenance
Section.Text: If there is any object that is obstructing a path of travel inside or outside of a terminal because of repairs or maintenance, it must be detectable by a person using a cane.

If a path of travel inside or outside of a terminal is not accessible to a person with a disability, including because there are stairs or escalators, there must be an alternative path of travel that is accessible to persons with disabilities and that allows them to access the desired service or reach the desired destination.

Subsection.Text: A terminal or any related facility that is subject to any requirement under this Division — including a shuttle bus or a light-rail train that operates between any facilities of a terminal — must be in good working order and properly maintained.

If any facilities that are referred to in subsection (1), including any amenities or equipment used in those facilities, are not in good working order, they must be repaired as soon as possible and, until they are repaired, measures must be taken that will result in a substantially equivalent or greater level of accessibility for persons with disabilities.

Heading.Label: PART 5
Heading.TitleText: Requirements Applicable to CATSA and CBSA

Section.MarginalNote: Services to assist persons with disabilities
Section.Text: During the security screening process, CATSA must, on the request of a person with a disability, provide the following services without delay:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: expediting the security screening process by directing the person, and any support person travelling with them, to the front of a line or to any other line that is intended to expedite the security screening process;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: permitting a representative of an air carrier or an individual with a security pass issued by an air carrier or the airport to accompany the person through the security screening checkpoint;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: assisting the person with proceeding through the steps of the security screening process, including by providing verbal or visual cues or additional instructions; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: assisting the person with the placement of carry-on baggage and personal items on a screening belt and with their retrieval.

Section.MarginalNote: Assistive device, support person or service dog

Subsection.Text: CATSA must, when screening a person with a disability who uses an assistive device or who is travelling with a support person or a service dog, make every reasonable effort to carry out the screening simultaneously with the screening of the person’s assistive device, support person or service dog, as the case may be.
If CATSA removes an assistive device from a person with a disability for a separate screening, CATSA must return the assistive device to the person without delay after it has been screened.
If CATSA removes an assistive device that is a mobility aid from a person with a disability for a separate screening, CATSA must offer a chair to the person while the mobility aid is being screened.

Section.MarginalNote: Services to assist persons with disabilities
Section.Text: During the border clearance process, the CBSA must, on the request of a person with a disability, provide the following services without delay:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: expediting the border clearance process by directing the person, and any support person travelling with them, to the front of the line or to any other line that is intended to expedite the border clearance process;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: assisting the person with proceeding through the steps of the border clearance process, including by providing verbal or visual cues or additional instructions;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: assisting the person to complete a declaration card or by collecting a verbal declaration; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: assisting the person with the placement of personal items on a counter for inspection and with their retrieval, if the person must undergo more extensive clearance.

Subsection.Text: In any areas of a terminal that are used for the purposes of security screening or border clearance of passengers, CATSA and the CBSA must, with respect to any signage that is under their respective control, ensure that the signage

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is located at strategic points throughout those areas, such as close to washrooms and exits;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is positioned to avoid shadow areas and glare and have a glare-free surface;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is colour-contrasted with its background; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: except in the case of electronic signage, meets the requirements set out in clauses 4.5.3 to 4.5.7 of CSA B651-18.

Subsection.Text: CATSA and the CBSA must ensure that electronic signage

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has letters, numbers, symbols and pictographs that slowly scroll across the screen and are colour-contrasted with their background but are not in red on a black background; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meets the requirements set out in clauses 4.5.3 to 4.5.5 of CSA B651-18.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (2) to (4), these Regulations come into force on the first anniversary of the day on which they are registered.
Sections 72, 73, 97, 98, 143, 144, and 225 and subsection 227(4) come into force on the second anniversary of the day on which these Regulations are registered.
Sections 11, 69, 70, 92 to 95, 140, 141, 188, 189, 190, 191, 223 and 224 come into force on the third anniversary of the day on which these Regulations are registered.

If Bill C-81, introduced in the 1st session of the 42nd Parliament and entitled the Accessible Canada Act, receives royal assent, then sections 238 to 240 of these Regulations come into force on the day on which section 169 of that Act comes into force.
